newsitem.title: CHINA: China tightens guard around North Korean defector.
newsitem.headline: China tightens guard around North Korean defector.

text.p: South Korea on Tuesday searched for a way to break an impasse over a high-level North Korean figure holed up in its embassy in Beijing after Pyongyang appeared to back away from its hard line on the defection.

However, Chinese police guarding the mission where Hwang Jang-yop remained marooned for a seventh day went on higher alert, sending three armoured personnel carriers rumbling into the sedate diplomatic quarter overnight to back up squads of police armed with assault rifles.
Seoul and Beijing were working to find a solution to the three-way diplomatic crisis that has thrown relations between China and the two Koreas into turmoil, officials said.
"Negotiations with the Chinese government are still going on," said South Korean embassy spokesman Chang Moon Ik, but declined to give details.
He dismissed reports that three-way talks between Beijing, its old communist ally Pyongyang and its new capitalist friend Seoul were under way to break the deadlock over Hwang's fate.
In Seoul, officials said North Korea had appeared to suggest it might accept Hwang's defection by saying it would dismiss him if he sought asylum.
"It is certain North Korea is changing its attitude," said Kim Kyung-woong, a senior official at the state South-North Dialogue Office.

North Korea's Foreign Ministry said late on Monday it would fire Hwang, ranked 24th in Pyongyang's hierarchy and a senior aide to top leader Kim Jong-il, if he sought asylum in Seoul but warned of "decisive countermeasures" if it were proved he had been kidnapped by the South.
"Our stand is simple and clear. If he was kidnapped, we cannot tolerate it and we will take decisive countermeasures," the Foreign Ministry said.
"If he sought asylum, it means that he is a renegade and he is dismissed," it said, adding that it had asked Beijing to investigate what it called the disappearance of Hwang.

North Korea had so far maintained that Seoul kidnapped Hwang, architect of the Stalinist hermit nation's governing ideology of Juche, or strict self-reliance. Seoul dismissed the charge as preposterous.
The most senior leader to defect from North Korea spent his 74th birthday quietly on Monday, as former comrades outside demanded his return and issued harsh warnings to rival Seoul.
North Korean officials had kept vigil since the beginning of the crisis, but largely withdrew from the area on Tuesday.
China, an unwilling third party in the feuding between the two hostile sides of the Korean peninsula, has appealed to both sides to act calmly to resolve the affair.

The United States has urged Pyongyang to avoid all provocative actions and has said it is closely monitoring developments after an assassination attempt against a former North Korean defector near Seoul on Saturday night.

South Korea accused Pyongyang agents of shooting 32-year-old Li Il-nam in an attack that left him critically ill with a bullet still lodged in his skull. Doctors in Seoul said he was on life support and unlikely to regain consciousness.
The tussle over Hwang's defection is the latest flare-up in tense relations between the two Koreas, arch-enemies since the 1950-53 Korean civil war ended only in a truce.
